12.92.text:
In 1987, Tina Lord
found herself in quite the pickle.

16.56.text:
See, this gold digger made sure
she married sweet Cord Roberts

22.56.text:
But when Cord found out
Tina loved his money

24.80.text: as much as she loved him,

31.16.text: So Maria hired Max Holden to romance Tina

33.84.text:
and then made sure Cord didn't find out
Tina was pregnant with his baby.

37.60.text:
So Tina, still married
but thinking Cord didn't love her

42.72.text: Cord finally figured out what was going on

44.84.text:
and rushed after them,
but he was too late.

49.44.text:
strapped to a raft
and sent over a waterfall.

52.36.text: She and her baby were presumed dead.

55.32.text: Cord was sad for a bit,

58.36.text: but then he bounced right back

59.84.text:
with a supersmart
archaeologist named Kate,

63.24.text: and they had a gorgeous wedding

64.76.text:
until Tina, seemingly back from the dead,
ran into the church holding a baby.

80.92.text:
is how the soap opera "One Life to Live"
introduced a love story

87.56.text: Now, if you've ever seen a soap opera,

89.68.text:
you know the stories and the characters
can be exaggerated, larger than life,

94.60.text:
and if you're a fan,
you find that exaggeration fun,

99.60.text:
maybe you find them
melodramatic or unsophisticated.

102.32.text: Maybe you think watching soap operas

105.84.text:
that their bigness means
their lessons are small or nonexistent.

110.56.text: But I believe the opposite to be true.

113.44.text: Soap operas reflect life, just bigger.

117.92.text:
So there are real life lessons
we can learn from soap operas,

121.36.text:
and those lessons
are as big and adventurous

127.32.text:
Now, I've been a fan since I ran home
from the bus stop in second grade

130.92.text:
desperate to catch the end
of Luke and Laura's wedding,

133.64.text:
the biggest moment
in "General Hospital" history.

138.32.text:
So you can imagine
how much I loved my eight years

141.68.text:
as the assistant casting director
on "As the World Turns."

144.68.text: My job was watching soap operas,

148.16.text:
and auditioning actors
to be on soap operas.

160.92.text:
but our lives can be filled
with as much intensity,

164.68.text: and the stakes can feel just as dramatic.

167.84.text: We cycle through tragedy and joy

172.12.text:
We cross thresholds, fight demons
and find salvation unexpectedly,

176.60.text: and we do it again and again and again,

179.60.text:
but just like soaps,
we can flip the script,

182.36.text:
which means we can learn
from these characters

189.08.text: And we can use those lessons

191.36.text: to craft our own life stories.

193.88.text: Soap operas teach us to push away doubt

205.28.text: And most importantly, they show us

207.60.text: it's never too late to change your story.

211.12.text:
So with that, let's start
with soap opera lesson one:

218.12.text:
"All My Children"'s Erica Kane
was daytime's version of Scarlett O'Hara,

225.20.text: who deep down was scrappy and daring.

228.80.text:
Now, in her 41 years on TV,
perhaps Erica's most famous scene

232.44.text: is her alone in the woods

234.44.text: suddenly face to face with a grizzly bear.

242.60.text: You may not come near me!

246.44.text: and you are a filthy beast!"

250.92.text: And of course the bear left,

254.44.text: is obstacles are to be expected

256.52.text:
and we can choose to surrender
or we can stand and fight.

261.24.text:
Pandora's Tim Westergren
knows this better than most.

264.08.text:
You might even call him
the Erica Kane of Silicon Valley.

268.00.text:
Tim and his cofounders
launched the company

270.08.text: with two million dollars in funding.

271.84.text: They were out of cash the next year.

274.84.text:
Now, lots of companies fold at that point,
but Tim chose to fight.

278.60.text:
He maxed out 11 credit cards
and racked up six figures in personal debt

284.68.text:
So every two weeks for two years on payday
he stood in front of his employees

289.56.text:
and he asked them
to sacrifice their salaries,

294.52.text:
More than 50 people deferred
two million dollars,

297.36.text: and now, more than a decade later,

302.36.text: When you believe that there is a way

304.84.text:
around or through
whatever is in front of you,

307.24.text: that surrender is not an option,

313.96.text: Which brings us to soap opera lesson two:

315.96.text:
sacrifice your ego
and drop the superiority complex.

322.32.text:
It's an acknowledgment
of need or fallibility.

326.92.text:
that we're not as special
as we might like to think.

331.12.text:
Stephanie Forrester
of "The Bold and the Beautiful"

333.56.text: thought she was pretty darn special.

335.32.text: She thought she was so special,

336.84.text:
she didn't need to mix
with the riffraff from the valley,

339.56.text:
and she made sure
valley girl Brooke knew it.

342.44.text:
But after nearly 25 years
of epic fighting,

345.88.text: Stephanie got sick and let Brooke in.

352.76.text: and Stephanie died in Brooke's arms,

362.56.text: and our ability to experience joy

365.40.text: and love and to improve our reality

367.92.text:
comes only when we make
ourselves vulnerable

370.96.text:
and we accept responsibility
for our actions

375.52.text:
kind of like Howard Schultz,
the CEO of Starbucks.

378.92.text: Now, after a great run as CEO,

389.48.text: and one of the first things he did

398.80.text:
And then he asked for help,
honesty, and ideas in return.

402.80.text: And now, Starbucks has more than doubled

405.40.text: its net revenue since Howard came back.

408.16.text:
So sacrifice your desire
to be right or safe all the time.

412.12.text: It's not helping anyone, least of all you.

424.24.text: You're not meant to be static characters.

426.96.text:
On television, static equals boring
and boring equals fired.

430.92.text:
Characters are supposed
to grow and change.

434.56.text: Now, on TV, those dynamic changes

437.04.text: can make for some rough transitions,

439.32.text:
particularly when a character
is played by one person yesterday

442.72.text: and played by someone new today.

445.84.text: Recasting happens all the time on soaps.

451.40.text:
four different actors
have played the same key role

457.72.text:
Each new face triggered a change
in the character's life and personality.

462.88.text:
Now, there was always
an essential nugget of Carly in there,

466.96.text:
but the character and the story
adapted to whomever was playing her.

471.64.text: And here's what that means for us.

474.40.text:
While we may not swap faces
in our own lives,

478.96.text:
We can choose to draw a circle
around our feet and stay in that spot,

484.32.text: or we can open ourselves to opportunities

486.88.text:
like Carly, who went
from nursing student to hotel owner,

493.72.text: Julia was a World War II spy,

496.40.text:
and when the war ended,
she got married, moved to France,

499.76.text:
and decided to give
culinary school a shot.

503.08.text:
Julia, her books and her TV shows
revolutionized the way America cooks.

509.64.text:
We all have the power
to initiate change in our lives,

517.40.text:
but sometimes life chooses for us,
and we don't get a heads up.

521.00.text: Surprise slams us in the face.

523.20.text:
You're flat on the ground,
the air is gone,

527.96.text:
So thank goodness
for soap opera lesson four:

538.96.text:
In 1983, "Days of Our Lives"'
Stefano DiMera died of a stroke,

545.72.text:
he died when his car
plunged into the harbor,

548.48.text:
and yet he was back in 1985
with a brain tumor.

553.08.text: But before the tumor could kill him,

555.72.text:
Marlena shot him, and he tumbled
off a catwalk to his death.

560.44.text: And so it went for 30 years.

565.28.text: Even when we saw the body,

568.68.text: He's called the Phoenix for a reason.

572.72.text: And here's what that means for us.

575.00.text: As long as the show is still on the air,

585.56.text: Now, of course, just like life,

588.28.text:
soap operas do ultimately
meet the big finale.

592.32.text:
CBS canceled my show,
"As The World Turns," in December 2009,

597.28.text: and we shot our final episode

600.64.text: It was six months of dying

602.36.text:
and I rode that train
right into the mountain.

606.24.text:
And even though we were
in the middle of a huge recession

609.00.text:
and millions of people
were struggling to find work,

612.84.text: I somehow thought everything would be OK.

615.16.text:
So I packed up the kids
and the Brooklyn apartment,

617.88.text: and we moved in with my in-laws

624.92.text: Three months later, nothing was OK.

627.68.text:
That was when I watched
the final episode air,

632.92.text:
and I realized the show
was not the only fatality.

639.12.text:
I was unemployed
and living on the second floor

643.32.text:
and that's enough
to make anyone feel dead inside.

648.04.text: But I knew my story wasn't over,

652.44.text:
I just had to tap into everything
I had ever learned about soap operas.

658.36.text:
I had to be brave like Erica
and refuse to surrender,

661.92.text: so every day, I made a decision to fight.

666.00.text: I had to be vulnerable like Stephanie

670.16.text:
I had to ask for help
a lot of times across many states.

674.76.text: I had to be adaptable like Carly

678.24.text:
and evolve my skills,
my mindset, and my circumstances,

681.80.text:
and then I had to be
resilient, like Stefano,

684.80.text: and resurrect myself and my career

687.48.text: like a phoenix from the ashes.

693.64.text: After 15 years in news and entertainment,

701.84.text: I had an offer for an entry level job.

706.92.text: and I was back from the dead.

710.24.text:
We will all experience
what looks like an ending,

713.36.text: and we can choose to make it a beginning.

716.12.text:
Kind of like Tina, who miraculously
survived that waterfall,

720.24.text:
and because I hate to leave
a cliffhanger hanging,

722.96.text: Tina and Cord did get divorced,

725.16.text:
but they got remarried three times
before the show went off the air in 2012.

732.84.text: as long as there is breath in your body,

736.32.text: it's never too late to change your story.
